subNodes.conversationText: root
The vision was over.
[Continue.]
"Get up off the floor, Nunny. What if he comes in and sees you like this?"
[Continue.]

"I don't care! I don't. Kill him, witch. He deserves it."

Knott moved on the table again. The gourd was getting bigger.
[Continue.]
"Here he comes, Nunny. Get up!"
[Continue.]
Nunny reluctantly did as she was told.
[Continue.]

"Please, witch. Believe me. What you just heard -- there's nothing to it. Nunny -- she's talking nonsense. Maybe you put her under some kind of spell. I don't know why you'd do that. But Sudder doesn't mean any harm. He's done nothing wrong. Please -- Just leave. We're fine here. Just leave."
[Continue.]
Sudder came in, covered with dirt and gore.
[Continue.]
"That was a damned bit of trouble. If I didn't know better I'd say the thing was still alive. What are you all looking at? Nunny, clean up that wine -- there's a pool of it dripping onto the floor."
[Continue.]
Then he took a step back. "Witch, your gourd --"
[Continue.]
Knott was himself again.
[Continue.]

Grim and silent, he stood up. He dwarfed the tiny room. Had he grown even bigger?

The gourd picked up the table and hurled it against the flimsy screen. The women screamed. Sudder darted for the exit and found <FirstName> blocking the way.
<FirstName> took a moment to think.

The vision had shown <him/her>, and Nunny had told <him/her>, that this man was a murderer. <He/She> expected the arrow would not contradict them. But the vision might be false, and Jalbetha's testimony cast doubt on what Nunny said.

And the arrow -- well, the young witch wouldn't want <his/her> own fate resting on such doubtful evidence of guilt or innocence.
Still, it wouldn't hurt to ask for one of the arrows, so <he/she> did.
"What? My arrows?"
"Go," the witch said the witch to Sudder, opening the door.

The vision had shown <him/her>, and Nunny had told <him/her>, that this man was a murderer. <He/She> expected the arrow would not contradict them. But the vision might be false, as the other had been, and Jalbetha's testimony cast doubt on what Nunny said.

And the arrow -- well, the young witch wouldn't want <his/her> own fate resting on such doubtful evidence of guilt or innocence. It had failed <him/her> once before.
Still, it wouldn't hurt to ask for one of the arrows, so <he/she> did.
"Go," the witch said the witch to Sudder, opening the door.

The vision had shown <him/her>, and Nunny had told <him/her>, that this man was a murderer. <He/She> expected the arrow would not contradict them. But the vision might be false, and Jalbetha's testimony cast doubt on what Nunny said.

And the arrow -- well, the young witch wouldn't want <his/her> own fate resting on such doubtful evidence of guilt or innocence. All the hunters hunted with arrows made by the woodcutter's son.
Still, it wouldn't hurt to ask for one of the arrows, so <he/she> did.
"Go," the witch said the witch to Sudder, opening the door.

The vision had shown <him/her>, and Nunny had told <him/her>, that this man was a murderer. <He/She> expected the arrow would not contradict them. But the vision might be false, as the other had been, and Jalbetha's testimony cast doubt on what Nunny said.

And the arrow -- well, the young witch wouldn't want <his/her> own fate resting on such doubtful evidence of guilt or innocence. It had failed <him/her> once before -- and all the hunters hunted with arrows made by the woodcutter's son.
Still, it wouldn't hurt to ask for one of the arrows, so <he/she> did.
"Go," the witch said the witch to Sudder, opening the door.
"Go," the witch said the witch to Sudder, opening the door.

Eyes wide, Sudder ran out. After a moment, Jalbetha followed him.

Nunny crept to the young witch, shrinking away from Knott, who stood stock-still in the center of the room.
[Continue.]

"I'm glad you didn't listen to me. I don't know what I was saying. I couldn't really hear myself talking for some reason. I don't know what we did to make you so mad. I don't know. I just don't know. I hope it wasn't my fault."

Then she left too.
[End.]
"Show me one of the arrows you hunt with."
"What? My arrows?"
"You heard me."
Sudder took out an arrow and gave it to <him/her>. It was made in the same was as the one that killed Nnenne.
"Knott, kill him."

Knott bludgeoned Sudder with a chair. The hunter didn't know how to resist and hardly did.

Jalbetha and Nunny screamed and ran out of shack and into the woods, and where they went the young witch would never know.
[Continue.]
As the man's life ebbed away, <FirstName> drained him of a pint of blood.
[End.]
<FirstName> took out her dagger and stabbed the hunter through the heart.

Despite everything, the hunter hadn't expected the attack.

Jalbetha and Nunny screamed and ran out of shack and into the woods, and where they went the young witch would never know.
[Continue.]
<He/She> couldn't bring <him/her>self to kill this man.
"Please. I just want to leave," the hunter pleaded.
"Go," the witch said the witch to Sudder, opening the door.
"Knott, kill him."
Sudder took out an arrow and gave it to <him/her>. Like the one that killed Nnenne, it looked like it was made by the woodcutter's son.
"Knott, kill him."
<FirstName> took out her dagger and stabbed the hunter through the heart.
The witch nodded and held out <his/her> hand.
Sudder took out an arrow and gave it to <him/her>. It was made in the same was as the one that killed Nnenne.
Sudder took out an arrow and gave it to <him/her>. Like the one that killed Nnenne, it looked like it was made by the woodcutter's son.
"Tell me. Did you kill Nnenne?"

"Nnenne?" As soon as the name was out, quivering in the air between them, the witch got dizzy. <He/She> saw the vision of Sudder stalking Nnenne through the woods over again, but, just as with the vision <he/she>'d experienced with the other hunter, it seemed artificial, an imposition on <his/her> imagination.
<FirstName> took a moment to think.
"Go," the witch said the witch to Sudder, opening the door.
"Show me one of the arrows you hunt with."

"Nnenne?" As soon as the name was out, quivering in the air between them, the witch got dizzy. Parts of the vision <he/she> had returned -- the hunter, the arrow, Nnenne --, but they were jumbled, stylized, theatrical, the work of an author, not a glimpse of breathing, human conflict.
<FirstName> took a moment to think.
"Show me one of the arrows you hunt with."
"Go," the witch said the witch to Sudder, opening the door.
[Continue.]

<FirstName> put <his/her> hand on the table to steady <him/her>self.

Nunny was still pleading her case, and Jalbetha was still scolding her with harsh whispers.
[Continue.]
"Get up off the floor, Nunny. What if he comes in and sees you like this?"
[Continue.]
It felt just like the other vision of Nnenne's death -- or did it? Did this one seem more real? If so, why? Because it was?
[Continue.]

<FirstName> put <his/her> hand on the table to steady <him/her>self.

Nunny was still pleading her case, and Jalbetha was still scolding her with harsh whispers.
